page.title: 11SALTMARSH ON ARNE PENINSULA
page.content: Mudflats or Saltings form a Spartinetum dominated by Spartina-a saltmarsh grass introduced to Britain in the 19th century and now dominating most tidal marshes.Also found are other halophytic species:Sea Lavender, Sea Spurrey,Sea Purslaine,Sea Plantain, Sea Aster and Arrow Grass. Like the submerged Eelgrass of the shallow waters,this vegetation supports many invertebrate animals so is an important feeding area for resident waders and winter migrants like Brent Geese.Colonies of marsh-nesting birds also breed there particularly large groups of Black-headed gulls on the salt flats between Long Island and Round Island to the east of the Arne peninsula.The saltings are feeding grounds for many herons from nearby Brownsea Island.
